title: 113_s836
content: The "Working Families Tax Relief Act of 2013" is the short title of the Act. It includes a permanent extension and modifications to the Child Tax Credit. The "Working Families Tax Relief Act of 2013" includes a permanent extension of the increase in the refundable portion of the Child Tax Credit. The amendment reduces the amount from $10,000 to $3,000 and eliminates inflation adjustments. Additionally, there are inflation adjustments for taxable years after 2012. The amendment increases the dollar amount for the cost-of-living adjustment for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012. The increase is rounded to the nearest multiple of $50. SEC. 3. PERMANENT EXTENSION OF MODIFICATIONS TO EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to increase the credit percentage for families with 3 or more children. The table for eligible individuals with 3 or more qualifying children will now apply a credit percentage of 45 instead of 40. Additionally, joint returns will see an increase of $5,000. Section 32(j)(1)(B) of the Internal Revenue Code is amended to increase the credit amount from $3,000 to $5,000, update subsection references, and change the applicable calendar year from 2007 to 2008. A conforming amendment is made to Section 32(b) by striking paragraph (3). These amendments will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being strengthened by increasing the credit amount from $3,000 to $5,000 and updating subsection references for taxable years starting after December 31, 2012. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced by raising the credit amounts for individuals with no qualifying children, increasing from $4,220 to $8,820 and from $5,280 to $10,425. Inflation adjustments are also made to ensure the credit keeps pace with rising costs. The Earned Income Tax Credit is being enhanced by increasing the credit amounts for individuals with no children, raising it to $8,820 and $10,425. Adjustments are made to ensure the credit keeps pace with rising costs, including changes to the age eligibility criteria. The amendments made by this section will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2012, changing the age eligibility criteria for the Earned Income Tax Credit. SEC. 5. Simplifying the Earned Income Tax Credit by changing age eligibility criteria. Modification of Abandoned Spouse Rule in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is modified for married individuals living apart with a qualifying child for more than half of the taxable year. The definition of marriage is adjusted to exclude individuals with a legally binding separation agreement and not living in the same household as their spouse by the end of the year. Amendments are made to sections 32(c)(1)(A) and 32(d) of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to eliminate the Disqualified Investment Income Test for married individuals. Section 32 of the Code is revised by removing subsection (i) and making conforming amendments to subsection (j). Rounding rules are also adjusted for certain dollar amounts. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to simplify rules regarding the presence of a qualifying child for the tax credit. If the amount is not a multiple of $10, it will be rounded to the nearest multiple of $10. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to simplify rules for claiming a qualifying child for the tax credit. If multiple eligible individuals claim the same child, one can be considered without a qualifying child for the credit. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to simplify rules for claiming a qualifying child for the tax credit. If multiple eligible individuals claim the same child, one can be considered without a qualifying child for the credit. Additionally, taxpayers may be eligible for the credit for a worker without a qualifying child if the qualifying children do not have a valid social security number. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2012 for individuals with qualifying children.
